Award.AwardTitle: Ensemble Estimation of Central Tropical Pacific Climate over the last 6,000 Years
Award.AbstractNarration:
Significant uncertainty surrounds future climate change impacts in many regions of the world, particularly regarding potential changes in tropical rainfall levels, and their extremes. Much of the uncertainty stems from poor constraints on future trends in the El Nino-Southern Oscillation (ENSO), a natural climate cycle that affects temperature and rainfall patterns around the globe, with its largest effects in the tropics. The instrumental record of ENSO is too short to isolate statistically robust trends, so this study seeks to provide hundreds of years worth of additional observations of past ENSO variability in an effort to: 1) quantify the natural baseline for this globally-relevant climate cycle, and 2) assess whether recent changes fall outside the range of natural variability. Using a suite of well-dated and high-resolution coral records from the central tropical Pacific, the study will extend the record of ENSO and longer-term climate patterns in the heart of the ENSO region. As such, it will inform future projections of tropical Pacific climate and constrain regional rainfall trends throughout the tropics and beyond.

Tropical Pacific climate trends are difficult to isolate from the short instrumental record of climate, owing to significant tropical climate variability on interannual to decadal timescales. Recent paleoclimate records hint that the El Nino-Southern Oscillation (ENSO) may be intensifying in response to anthropogenic climate forcing, implying that tropical rainfall extremes may increase in coming decades. Such records also show that natural ENSO variability is much larger than previously thought, requiring a larger number of paleo-reconstruction to define natural ENSO variability and distinguish it from possible anthropogenic signals. The last 6,000 years is an particularly important baseline for probing past ENSO variability, as global climate models show that ENSO may be sensitive to a range of natural climate forcings over this period. This project involves generation of a highly-replicated reconstruction of both mean climate and climate variability in the tropical Pacific over the last 6,000 years using hundreds of fossil coral records from Christmas Island (2ºN, 157ºW), which lies in the heart of the El Niño-Southern Oscillation (ENSO) region. The research team, which includes a graduate student, will compare the new reconstructions to numerical climate model simulations of tropical Pacific paleoclimate variability, probing the relationships between climate forcing, mean climate state, and ENSO variability.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Project Outcomes

 

Projections of future climate change impacts provide critical insights to guide preparations for changes in regional temperature and rainfall patterns.  Such projections are currently marked by large uncertainties in many regions of the world, in part because any potential changes in the statistics of climate extremes are difficult to resolve in the short instrumental record of climate. This is especially true for the largest source of year-to-year climate variability, the El Niño-Southern Oscillation (ENSO), which alters temperature and rainfall patterns around the world during its warm and cool extremes. ENSO arises from ocean-atmosphere interactions in the tropical Pacific Ocean, where instrumental records of climate are especially sparse.

 

In this project, we recovered and analyzed coral skeletons as a well-established archive of past tropical ocean temperatures at Christmas Island, where ENSO impacts are especially pronounced. By combining living coral material drilled from the modern reef with older, so-called “fossil” corals collected on beaches and subsequently dated with radiometric techniques, we compiled a reconstruction of ENSO extremes going back 6,000 years before present. The reconstruction is based on the oxygen isotopic content of coral skeletons, as measured my mass spectrometry, which is virtually indistinguishable from instrumental sea-surface temperatures from Christmas Island over the last 40 years.

 

With a reconstruction totaling more than 2,500 years’ worth of monthly-resolved data, our results show that ENSO variability during the 20 century is significantly stronger than that of the pre-industrial period. This finding has immediate implications for the detection of a potential intensification in the powerful climate cycle caused by anthropogenic climate change – a scenario that has recently emerged from analysis of climate models forced by greenhouse gases (Cai et al., 2018). Taken together, these results imply that increased year-to-year variability in temperature and rainfall should be part of climate risk assessments in areas that are sensitive to ENSO.

 

Another key finding involves the evolution of ENSO variability during the pre-industrial period, when climate models suggest that a variety of natural climate forcings may have driven significant changes in ENSO behavior. By comparing datasets of ENSO variability with such model scenarios allows scientists to assess the accuracy of such models in projecting future climate change impacts. Our new coral-based dataset of ENSO variability suggests that a consistent behavior exhibited in models – a pronounced weakening of ENSO variability roughly 6-7 thousand years ago due to changes in the Earth’s orbit – cannot be detected against the rich background of millennial-scale and centennial-scale variability. Rather, we find that the only anomalous period in our reconstruction – apart from the 20thcentury, notably – is a significant weakening of ENSO from 3-5 thousand years ago. This shift may or may not be related to changes in orbital parameters, but if they are, then climate models may be missing some key aspects of the tropical Pacific response to such forcing. Conversely, our reconstruction may misrepresent large-scale ENSO variability during that time period, requiring the generation of additional climate reconstructions from across the tropical Pacific region.
